unit: Unit 8 | Inference for Categorical Data: Chi-Square
title: Projected 2022 Employment by Industry Sector
question_text:
The Bureau of Labor Statistics publishes information on the distribution of employment by major industry sector. In December 2013, they also published their predictions for the year 2022. These predictions are shown in the table below.
A researcher wants to investigate whether these predictions may already be true and has decided to do a study.
Assuming the appropriate conditions for inference have been met, what type of test and how many degrees of freedom should be used in analyzing the results?
tables:
Industry SectorPercent Distribution
Services-providing80.9
Goods-producing, excluding agriculture12.1
Non-agriculture self-employed and unpaid family worker5.8
Agriculture, forestry, fishing, and hunting1.2

choices.text: A one-sample $z$-test for proportions should be used. However, there is no need to use degrees of freedom with a $z$-test.

solution:
We are looking to compare gathered data against a specific model – namely the 2022 predictions provided by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. This model is provided using a table where all the percentages add up to $100\%$. Furthermore, the variable of interest (industry sector) is categorical.

All of these things should lead us to conclude that a ${ \chi }^{ 2 }$ Goodness of Fit Test is appropriate. For this type of test, the number of degrees of freedom ($df$) is $k – 1$ where $k$ is the number of different categories the variable can fall into. There are $4$ different major industry sectors, therefore: $4–1=3$ degrees of freedom.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect. We use $n–2$ degrees of freedom (where $n$ is the number of observations) only when conducting a $t$-test for linear regression.

Choice 'C' is incorrect. The degrees of freedom does not equal the number of different categories.

Choices 'D' and 'E' are incorrect. Although our model consists of various percentages (or proportions), and although our data should come from a single sample, we cannot use a $z$-test for proportions.

A $z$-test for proportions would be used when we have a single hypothesized proportion related to the overall population, not several hypothesized proportions related to various categories within the overall population.

Also, Choice 'D' is incorrect because degrees of freedom are irrelevant when working with a $z$-distribution.
